required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Outcome After Avascular Necrosis of the Femoral Head in Young Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Outcome After Avascular Necrosis of the Femoral Head in Young Patients - Retrospective Analysis With a Min. 10-year Follow-up

brief_summary.textblock:
1. The course of AVN between Initial diagnosis and total hip replacement (THA) is analysed. The impact of early interventions versus conservative therapy in AVN before THA will be evaluated.
2. The short and long term outcomes of AVN patients undergoing THA with respect to complications, reoperations and quality of life are investigated. Potential risk factors for adverse outcomes will be investigated.

detailed_description.textblock:
The study is to describe the course of avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head from initial diagnosis and to collect data on treatment options and the further course in these cases. The duration from initial diagnosis of AVN to joint replacement as total hip arthroplasty (THA) will be analysed and the course after joint replacement with potential short- and long-term complications will be evaluated.
The impact of THA after AVN on activities of daily living will be assessed by Euroquol 5 Dimensions (EQ-5D-5L) and Hip disability and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (HOOS) questionnaires.

clinical_study.why_stopped: difficulty enrolling patients, no patient recruited

primary_outcome.time_frame: single time point assessment at baseline
primary_outcome.description: time from first diagnosis of AVN to joint replacement = time to event data (in the years between 1999-2006)

primary_outcome.time_frame: single time point assessment at baseline
primary_outcome.description: reoperation after THA = time to event data (in the years between 2000-2007)

secondary_outcome.measure: Hip disability and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (HOOS)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: single time point assessment at baseline
secondary_outcome.description: 40 item questionnaire to assess patient-relevant outcomes in five separate subscales (pain, symptoms, activity of daily living, sport and recreation function and hip related quality of life). Scores are: None, Mild, Moderate, Severe, Extreme

secondary_outcome.time_frame: single time point assessment at baseline
secondary_outcome.description: Five dimensions: mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort and anxiety/depression. Each dimension has 5 levels: no problems, slight problems, moderate problems, severe problems and extreme problems.

clinical_study.condition: Avascular Necrosis of the Femoral Head

arm_group.description: Patients with a first AVN-related contact (initial or confirmed diagnosis) at the Universit√§tsspital Basel (USB) or Kantonsspital Basel-Liestal (KSBL) in the years between 1999-2006 (being assessed by questionnaires for patient reported outcome and questionnaire for course of the disease)
Patients with a THA because of AVN in the years 2000-2007 (being assessed by questionnaires for patient reported outcome and questionnaire for course of the disease)

intervention.description: questionnaires with respect to outcomes: Reoperations Short term complications Long term complications EQ-5D (current) HOOS (current) disease related change of occupation use of walking aids comorbidities medication

intervention.intervention_name: questionnaire for course of the disease

study_pop.textblock:
Population 1: Patients with a first AVN-related contact (initial or confirmed diagnosis) at the USB or KSBL Liestal in the years between 1999-2006.
Population 2: Patients with a THA because of AVN at the USB or KSBL Liestal in the years 2000-2007.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- MRI of the hip available from diagnosis at the USB or KSBL Liestal
- Informed Consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Insufficient knowledge of project languages (English, German, French)

overall_official.affiliation: Dep. of Orthopedic and Trauma Surgery; University Hospital Basel
